definition: theatrical work (play, opera, TV series etc)/dramatic (change, increase etc)/acute/severe

home/family/(polite) my (sister, uncle etc)/classifier for families or businesses/refers to the philosophical schools of pre-Han China/noun suffix for a specialist in some activity, such as a musician or revolutionary, corresponding to English -ist, -er, -ary or -ian/CL:個|个[ge4]

sentences.english: He is a member of Shanghai Dramatists Association.
sentences.chinese: 现为上海戏剧家协会会员。

sentences.english: Tian Han is known as a dramatist in literature history.
sentences.chinese: 文学史上的田汉以戏剧家闻名。

sentences.english: With the inborn bold and unconstrained temperament, the Ming dramatist Shen Zizheng was known for his roving experience like a brave.
sentences.chinese: 明代戏剧家沈自征其性格和气质颇具游侠色彩。

sentences.english: The dramatist Guan Hanqing had the lofty status in the history of Chinese literature in the Han dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 元代戏剧家关汉卿在中国文学史上有着崇高的地位。

definition: School of Minor-talks, one of the Hundred Schools of Thought 諸子百家|诸子百家[zhu1 zi3 bai3 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Tang Xianzu (1550-1616), Ming poet and dramatist, author of The Peony Pavilion 牡丹亭[Mu3 dan5 Ting2]
Anton Pavlovich Chekhov (1860-1904), Russian writer famous for his short stories and plays
Henrik Ibsen (1828-1906), Norwegian dramatist, author of Doll's House 玩偶之家
Guan Hanqing (c. 1235-c. 1300), Yuan dynasty dramatist in the 雜劇|杂剧 tradition of musical comedy, one of the Four Great Yuan dramatists 元曲四大家
Molière (1622-1673), French playwright and actor, master of comedy

pinyin: Wei1 lian2 · Sha1 shi4 bi3 ya4

definition: George Bernard Shaw (1856-1950), Irish dramatist and writer
Shakespeare/slang or popular culture abbr. of 莎士比亞|莎士比亚[Sha1 shi4 bi3 ya4]
